name: pandas
description: Powerful data structures for data analysis, time series, and statistics
author: The Pandas Development Team
fullDescription: pandas is a Python package that provides fast, flexible, and expressive data structures designed to make working with "relational" or "labeled" data both easy and intuitive. It aims to be the fundamental high-level building block for doing practical, real-world data analysis in Python.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# conda
conda install -c conda-forge pandas

# or PyPI
pip install pandas
pypiData.usageExample:
import pandas as pd

# Create a DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'Age': [25, 30, 35],
    'City': ['New York', 'London', 'Tokyo']
})

print(df)
features: Easy handling of missing data (NaN, NA, NaT)
Size mutability: columns can be inserted and deleted
Robust I/O tools for CSV, Excel, databases
pypiData.additionalInfo: pandas is built on top of NumPy and is intended to integrate well within a scientific computing environment with many other 3rd party libraries.

advancedUsage.title: Data Loading and Saving
advancedUsage.description: Read and write data from various formats:
advancedUsage.example:
import pandas as pd

# Read from CSV
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Read from Excel
df = pd.read_excel('data.xlsx')

# Save to different formats
df.to_csv('output.csv', index=False)
df.to_excel('output.xlsx', index=False)
df.to_json('output.json')

vulnerabilities.description: Improper validation of specified quantity in input
Timezone data inconsistency in historical calculations

name: boto3
description: The AWS SDK for Python (Boto3) provides a Python API for AWS infrastructure services. An easy to use, object-oriented API as well as low-level access to AWS services.
author: Amazon Web Services
fullDescription: Boto3 is the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Software Development Kit (SDK) for Python, which allows Python developers to write software that makes use of services like Amazon S3 and Amazon EC2. You can find the latest, most up to date, documentation at our doc site, including a list of services that are supported.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/boto/boto3.git
cd boto3
python -m pip install -r requirements.txt
python -m pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import boto3
s3 = boto3.resource('s3')
for bucket in s3.buckets.all():
    print(bucket.name)
pypiData.additionalInfo: After installing boto3, you'll need to set up credentials in ~/.aws/credentials and configure a default region in ~/.aws/config.

advancedUsage.title: Using Sessions
advancedUsage.description: Create a session to manage configuration and credentials:
advancedUsage.example:
import boto3

session = boto3.Session(
    aws_access_key_id='YOUR_KEY',
    aws_secret_access_key='YOUR_SECRET',
    region_name='us-east-1'
)

s3 = session.resource('s3')

components.name: boto3
components.description: The AWS SDK for Python

components.name: botocore
components.description: Low-level, data-driven core of boto 3

components.name: jmespath
components.description: JSON Matching Expressions

components.name: s3transfer
components.description: An Amazon S3 Transfer Manager

name: tensorflow
description: TensorFlow is an open source machine learning framework for everyone
author: Google Inc.
fullDescription: TensorFlow is an end-to-end open source platform for machine learning. It has a comprehensive, flexible ecosystem of tools, libraries, and community resources that lets researchers push the state-of-the-art in ML and developers easily build and deploy ML-powered applications.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# GPU version
pip install tensorflow-gpu==2.16.1

# CPU version
pip install tensorflow==2.16.1
pypiData.usageExample:
import tensorflow as tf

# Create a simple model
model = tf.keras.Sequential([
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(128, activation='relu'),
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(10, activation='softmax')
])

model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy', metrics=['accuracy'])
pypiData.additionalInfo: TensorFlow supports both CPU and GPU computation and provides APIs for multiple programming languages including Python, C++, and JavaScript.

name: torch
description: Tensors and Dynamic neural networks in Python with strong GPU acceleration
author: PyTorch Team
fullDescription: PyTorch is a Python package that provides tensor computation with strong GPU acceleration and deep neural networks built on a tape-based autograd system.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# CPU version
pip install torch torchvision torchaudio --index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cpu

# CUDA version
pip install torch torchvision torchaudio --index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu121
pypiData.usageExample:
import torch
import torch.nn as nn

# Create a simple neural network
model = nn.Sequential(
    nn.Linear(784, 128),
    nn.ReLU(),
    nn.Linear(128, 10)
)

# Create a tensor
x = torch.randn(32, 784)
output = model(x)
pypiData.additionalInfo: PyTorch provides a flexible platform for deep learning research and production with dynamic computation graphs and extensive GPU support.

name: transformers
description: State-of-the-art Machine Learning for JAX, PyTorch and TensorFlow
author: Hugging Face Inc.
fullDescription: Transformers provides thousands of pretrained models to perform tasks on different modalities such as text, vision, and audio. These models can be applied on text for tasks like text classification, information extraction, question answering, summarization, translation, text generation, and more.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# For PyTorch
pip install transformers[torch]

# For TensorFlow
pip install transformers[tf]
pypiData.usageExample:
from transformers import AutoTokenizer, AutoModel

# Load a pre-trained model and tokenizer
tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained('bert-base-uncased')
model = AutoModel.from_pretrained('bert-base-uncased')

# Tokenize and encode text
inputs = tokenizer('Hello, my dog is cute', return_tensors='pt')
outputs = model(**inputs)
pypiData.additionalInfo: The library provides APIs and tools to easily download and train state-of-the-art pretrained models.

name: numpy
description: Fundamental package for array computing in Python
author: NumPy Developers
fullDescription: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# conda
conda install numpy

# or from source
git clone https://github.com/numpy/numpy.git
cd numpy
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import numpy as np

# Create arrays
a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
b = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])

# Basic operations
print(a * 2)
print(np.dot(a, a))
pypiData.additionalInfo: NumPy is the foundation of the Python scientific computing stack and is used by virtually every scientific Python package.

advancedUsage.title: Array Creation
advancedUsage.description: Create arrays using various methods:
advancedUsage.example:
import numpy as np

# From lists
a = np.array([1, 2, 3])

# Using functions
b = np.zeros((3, 4))
c = np.ones((2, 3, 4))
d = np.arange(0, 10, 2)

vulnerabilities.description: Potential buffer overflow in array indexing

name: requests
description: Python HTTP for Humans. A simple, yet elegant, HTTP library.
author: Kenneth Reitz
fullDescription: Requests is an elegant and simple HTTP library for Python, built for human beings. Requests allows you to send HTTP/1.1 requests extremely easily. There's no need to manually add query strings to your URLs, or to form-encode your PUT & POST data  but nowadays, just use the json method!

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/psf/requests.git
cd requests
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import requests
r = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/basic-auth/user/pass', auth=('user', 'pass'))
print(r.status_code)  # 200
print(r.headers['content-type'])  # 'application/json; charset=utf8'
print(r.encoding)  # 'utf-8'
print(r.text)  # '{"authenticated": true, ...'
print(r.json())  # {'authenticated': True, ...}
pypiData.additionalInfo: Requests is one of the most downloaded Python packages today, pulling in around 30M downloads/week. According to GitHub, Requests is currently depended upon by 1,000,000+ repositories.

advancedUsage.title: Using Sessions
advancedUsage.description: Sessions allow you to persist cookies and other parameters across requests:
advancedUsage.example:
import requests

s = requests.Session()
s.auth = ('user', 'pass')
s.headers.update({'x-test': 'true'})

# Both requests will use the session's auth and headers
r1 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/headers')
r2 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/user')

vulnerabilities.description: Potential cookie leakage on redirect

name: flask
description: A simple framework for building complex web applications.
author: Pallets
fullDescription: Flask is a lightweight WSGI web application framework. It is designed to make getting started quick and easy, with the ability to scale up to complex applications. It began as a simple wrapper around Werkzeug and Jinja and has become one of the most popular Python web application frameworks.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/pallets/flask.git
cd flask
pip install -e .
pypiData.additionalInfo: Flask provides configuration and conventions, with sensible defaults, to get started. This gives developers the flexibility they need to design and build their applications while providing tools and patterns to help with the common cases.

advancedUsage.title: Application Factory
advancedUsage.description: Use the application factory pattern for larger applications:
advancedUsage.example:
from flask import Flask

def create_app(config_name):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config[config_name])
    
    from .main import main as main_blueprint
    app.register_blueprint(main_blueprint)
    
    return app

vulnerabilities.description: Potential path traversal in static file serving

author: Django Software Foundation
fullDescription: Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. Built by experienced developers, it takes care of much of the hassle of web development, so you can focus on writing your app without needing to reinvent the wheel. It's free and open source.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/django/django.git
cd django
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
# Create a new Django project
django-admin startproject mysite
cd mysite

# Create an app
python manage.py startapp polls

# Run the development server
python manage.py runserver
pypiData.additionalInfo: Django follows the model-template-views architectural pattern and emphasizes reusability of components, less code, low coupling, and the principle of don't repeat yourself.

name: scikit-learn
description: A set of python modules for machine learning and data mining
author: The scikit-learn developers
fullDescription: Scikit-learn is a Python module for machine learning built on top of SciPy and is distributed under the 3-Clause BSD license. The project was started in 2007 by David Cournapeau as a Google Summer of Code project, and since then many volunteers have contributed. It is currently maintained by a team of volunteers.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn.git
cd scikit-learn
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
from sklearn import datasets, svm
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

# Load dataset
iris = datasets.load_iris()
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
    iris.data, iris.target, test_size=0.3)

# Train classifier
clf = svm.SVC(gamma='scale')
clf.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions
print(clf.score(X_test, y_test))
pypiData.additionalInfo: Scikit-learn provides a consistent interface across different machine learning algorithms, making it easy to experiment with different approaches and compare results.

advancedUsage.title: Pipeline and GridSearch
advancedUsage.description: Build machine learning pipelines with parameter tuning:
advancedUsage.example:
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.model_selection import GridSearchCV
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.svm import SVC

pipe = Pipeline([
    ('scaler', StandardScaler()),
    ('svc', SVC())
])

param_grid = {
    'svc__C': [0.1, 1, 10],
    'svc__gamma': ['scale', 'auto']
}

gridsearch = GridSearchCV(pipe, param_grid, cv=5)
gridsearch.fit(X_train, y_train)

vulnerabilities.description: Buffer overflow in sparse matrix operations

name: matplotlib
description: Python plotting package
author: The Matplotlib development team
fullDescription: Matplotlib is a comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations in Python. Matplotlib makes easy things easy and hard things possible. It provides a MATLAB-like plotting framework that is object-oriented and Pythonic.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib.git
cd matplotlib
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Create data
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

# Create plot
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(x, y, 'b-', linewidth=2)
plt.xlabel('X values')
plt.ylabel('Y values')
plt.title('Sine Wave')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
pypiData.additionalInfo: Matplotlib is the most popular Python plotting library and is used extensively in scientific computing, data analysis, and machine learning workflows.

advancedUsage.title: Subplots and Styling
advancedUsage.description: Create complex multi-panel figures with custom styling:
advancedUsage.example:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

fig, ((ax1, ax2), (ax3, ax4)) = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))

x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 100)

ax1.plot(x, np.sin(x), 'r-')
ax1.set_title('Sine')

ax2.plot(x, np.cos(x), 'g-')
ax2.set_title('Cosine')

ax3.plot(x, np.tan(x), 'b-')
ax3.set_title('Tangent')

ax4.plot(x, np.exp(-x), 'm-')
ax4.set_title('Exponential Decay')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

name: pillow
description: Python Imaging Library (Fork)
author: Jeffrey A. Clark (Alex) and contributors
fullDescription: The Python Imaging Library adds image processing capabilities to your Python interpreter. This library provides extensive file format support, an efficient internal representation, and fairly powerful image processing capabilities. The core image library is designed for fast access to data stored in a few basic pixel formats.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow.git
cd Pillow
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
from PIL import Image, ImageFilter

# Open an image
img = Image.open('example.jpg')

# Apply a filter
blurred = img.filter(ImageFilter.BLUR)

# Resize the image
resized = img.resize((800, 600))

# Save the result
resized.save('output.jpg')
pypiData.additionalInfo: Pillow is the friendly PIL fork by Jeffrey A. Clark (Alex) and contributors. PIL is the Python Imaging Library by Fredrik Lundh and contributors.

advancedUsage.description: Process multiple images efficiently:

name: urllib3
description: HTTP library with thread-safe connection pooling, file post, and more.
author: Andrey Petrov
fullDescription: urllib3 is a powerful, user-friendly HTTP client for Python. Much of the Python ecosystem already uses urllib3 and you should too. urllib3 brings many critical features that are missing from the Python standard libraries: Thread safety, Connection pooling, Client-side TLS/SSL verification, File uploads with multipart encoding, Helpers for retrying requests and dealing with HTTP redirects, Support for gzip, deflate, and brotli encoding, Proxy support for HTTP and SOCKS.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3.git
cd urllib3
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import urllib3

# Create a PoolManager instance
http = urllib3.PoolManager()

# Make a GET request
resp = http.request('GET', 'https://httpbin.org/json')
print(resp.status)
print(resp.data.decode('utf-8'))

# Make a POST request
resp = http.request('POST', 'https://httpbin.org/post', 
                   fields={'key': 'value'})
print(resp.status)
pypiData.additionalInfo: urllib3 is used by many popular Python packages including Requests, and is one of the most downloaded packages in the Python ecosystem.

advancedUsage.title: Connection Pooling
advancedUsage.description: Efficiently manage HTTP connections:
advancedUsage.example:
import urllib3

# Create a connection pool
http = urllib3.PoolManager(
    num_pools=10,
    maxsize=10,
    retries=urllib3.Retry(total=3, backoff_factor=0.1)
)

# Make multiple requests efficiently
for i in range(100):
    resp = http.request('GET', f'https://httpbin.org/delay/{i%3}')
    print(f'Request {i}: {resp.status}')

author: The Pandas Development Team

Size mutability: columns can be inserted and deleted
Robust I/O tools for CSV, Excel, databases
pypiData.additionalInfo: pandas is built on top of NumPy and is intended to integrate well within a scientific computing environment with many other 3rd party libraries.

advancedUsage.title: Data Loading and Saving
advancedUsage.description: Read and write data from various formats:
advancedUsage.example:
import pandas as pd

# Read from CSV
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Read from Excel
df = pd.read_excel('data.xlsx')

# Save to different formats
df.to_csv('output.csv', index=False)
df.to_excel('output.xlsx', index=False)
df.to_json('output.json')

vulnerabilities.description: Improper validation of specified quantity in input
Timezone data inconsistency in historical calculations

name: boto3
description: The AWS SDK for Python (Boto3) provides a Python API for AWS infrastructure services. An easy to use, object-oriented API as well as low-level access to AWS services.
author: Amazon Web Services
fullDescription: Boto3 is the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Software Development Kit (SDK) for Python, which allows Python developers to write software that makes use of services like Amazon S3 and Amazon EC2. You can find the latest, most up to date, documentation at our doc site, including a list of services that are supported.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/boto/boto3.git
cd boto3
python -m pip install -r requirements.txt
python -m pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import boto3
s3 = boto3.resource('s3')
for bucket in s3.buckets.all():
    print(bucket.name)
pypiData.additionalInfo: After installing boto3, you'll need to set up credentials in ~/.aws/credentials and configure a default region in ~/.aws/config.

advancedUsage.title: Using Sessions
advancedUsage.description: Create a session to manage configuration and credentials:
advancedUsage.example:
import boto3

session = boto3.Session(
    aws_access_key_id='YOUR_KEY',
    aws_secret_access_key='YOUR_SECRET',
    region_name='us-east-1'
)

s3 = session.resource('s3')

name: numpy
description: Fundamental package for array computing in Python
author: NumPy Developers
fullDescription: NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things: a powerful N-dimensional array object, sophisticated (broadcasting) functions, tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code, useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# conda
conda install numpy

# or from source
git clone https://github.com/numpy/numpy.git
cd numpy
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import numpy as np

# Create arrays
a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
b = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4]])

# Basic operations
print(a * 2)
print(np.dot(a, a))
pypiData.additionalInfo: NumPy is the foundation of the Python scientific computing stack and is used by virtually every scientific Python package.

advancedUsage.title: Array Creation
advancedUsage.description: Create arrays using various methods:
advancedUsage.example:
import numpy as np

# From lists
a = np.array([1, 2, 3])

# Using functions
b = np.zeros((3, 4))
c = np.ones((2, 3, 4))
d = np.arange(0, 10, 2)

vulnerabilities.description: Potential buffer overflow in array indexing

name: requests
description: Python HTTP for Humans. A simple, yet elegant, HTTP library.
author: Kenneth Reitz
fullDescription: Requests is an elegant and simple HTTP library for Python, built for human beings. Requests allows you to send HTTP/1.1 requests extremely easily. There's no need to manually add query strings to your URLs, or to form-encode your PUT & POST data  but nowadays, just use the json method!

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/psf/requests.git
cd requests
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import requests
r = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/basic-auth/user/pass', auth=('user', 'pass'))
print(r.status_code)  # 200
print(r.headers['content-type'])  # 'application/json; charset=utf8'
print(r.encoding)  # 'utf-8'
print(r.text)  # '{"authenticated": true, ...'
print(r.json())  # {'authenticated': True, ...}
pypiData.additionalInfo: Requests is one of the most downloaded Python packages today, pulling in around 30M downloads/week. According to GitHub, Requests is currently depended upon by 1,000,000+ repositories.

advancedUsage.title: Using Sessions
advancedUsage.description: Sessions allow you to persist cookies and other parameters across requests:
advancedUsage.example:
import requests

s = requests.Session()
s.auth = ('user', 'pass')
s.headers.update({'x-test': 'true'})

# Both requests will use the session's auth and headers
r1 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/headers')
r2 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/user')

vulnerabilities.description: Potential cookie leakage on redirect

name: flask
description: A simple framework for building complex web applications.
author: Pallets
fullDescription: Flask is a lightweight WSGI web application framework. It is designed to make getting started quick and easy, with the ability to scale up to complex applications. It began as a simple wrapper around Werkzeug and Jinja and has become one of the most popular Python web application frameworks.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/pallets/flask.git
cd flask
pip install -e .
pypiData.additionalInfo: Flask provides configuration and conventions, with sensible defaults, to get started. This gives developers the flexibility they need to design and build their applications while providing tools and patterns to help with the common cases.

advancedUsage.title: Application Factory
advancedUsage.description: Use the application factory pattern for larger applications:
advancedUsage.example:
from flask import Flask

def create_app(config_name):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config[config_name])
    
    from .main import main as main_blueprint
    app.register_blueprint(main_blueprint)
    
    return app

vulnerabilities.description: Potential path traversal in static file serving

name: django
description: A high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design.
author: Django Software Foundation
fullDescription: Django is a high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. Built by experienced developers, it takes care of much of the hassle of web development, so you can focus on writing your app without needing to reinvent the wheel. It's free and open source.

name: scikit-learn
description: A set of python modules for machine learning and data mining
author: The scikit-learn developers
fullDescription: Scikit-learn is a Python module for machine learning built on top of SciPy and is distributed under the 3-Clause BSD license. The project was started in 2007 by David Cournapeau as a Google Summer of Code project, and since then many volunteers have contributed. It is currently maintained by a team of volunteers.

vulnerabilities.description: Buffer overflow in sparse matrix operations

name: matplotlib
description: Python plotting package
author: The Matplotlib development team
fullDescription: Matplotlib is a comprehensive library for creating static, animated, and interactive visualizations in Python. Matplotlib makes easy things easy and hard things possible. It provides a MATLAB-like plotting framework that is object-oriented and Pythonic.

vulnerabilities.description: Arbitrary code execution via crafted image file

name: pillow
description: Python Imaging Library (Fork)
author: Jeffrey A. Clark (Alex) and contributors
fullDescription: The Python Imaging Library adds image processing capabilities to your Python interpreter. This library provides extensive file format support, an efficient internal representation, and fairly powerful image processing capabilities. The core image library is designed for fast access to data stored in a few basic pixel formats.

vulnerabilities.description: Buffer overflow in TIFF processing

name: urllib3
description: HTTP library with thread-safe connection pooling, file post, and more.
author: Andrey Petrov
fullDescription: urllib3 is a powerful, user-friendly HTTP client for Python. Much of the Python ecosystem already uses urllib3 and you should too. urllib3 brings many critical features that are missing from the Python standard libraries: Thread safety, Connection pooling, Client-side TLS/SSL verification, File uploads with multipart encoding, Helpers for retrying requests and dealing with HTTP redirects, Support for gzip, deflate, and brotli encoding, Proxy support for HTTP and SOCKS.

vulnerabilities.description: Certificate verification bypass via invalid headers

name: pandas
description: Powerful data structures for data analysis, time series, and statistics
author: The Pandas Development Team
fullDescription: pandas is a Python package that provides fast, flexible, and expressive data structures designed to make working with "relational" or "labeled" data both easy and intuitive. It aims to be the fundamental high-level building block for doing practical, real-world data analysis in Python.

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
# conda
conda install -c conda-forge pandas

# or PyPI
pip install pandas
pypiData.usageExample:
import pandas as pd

# Create a DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'Name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'Age': [25, 30, 35],
    'City': ['New York', 'London', 'Tokyo']
})

print(df)
features: Easy handling of missing data (NaN, NA, NaT)
Size mutability: columns can be inserted and deleted
Robust I/O tools for CSV, Excel, databases
pypiData.additionalInfo: pandas is built on top of NumPy and is intended to integrate well within a scientific computing environment with many other 3rd party libraries.

advancedUsage.title: Data Loading and Saving
advancedUsage.description: Read and write data from various formats:
advancedUsage.example:
import pandas as pd

# Read from CSV
df = pd.read_csv('data.csv')

# Read from Excel
df = pd.read_excel('data.xlsx')

# Save to different formats
df.to_csv('output.csv', index=False)
df.to_excel('output.xlsx', index=False)
df.to_json('output.json')

vulnerabilities.description: Improper validation of specified quantity in input
Timezone data inconsistency in historical calculations
Request smuggling vulnerability in HTTP parsing

name: requests
description: Python HTTP for Humans. A simple, yet elegant, HTTP library.
author: Kenneth Reitz
fullDescription: Requests is an elegant and simple HTTP library for Python, built for human beings. Requests allows you to send HTTP/1.1 requests extremely easily. There's no need to manually add query strings to your URLs, or to form-encode your PUT & POST data  but nowadays, just use the json method!

pypiData.alternativeInstallation:
git clone https://github.com/psf/requests.git
cd requests
pip install -e .
pypiData.usageExample:
import requests
r = requests.get('https://httpbin.org/basic-auth/user/pass', auth=('user', 'pass'))
print(r.status_code)  # 200
print(r.headers['content-type'])  # 'application/json; charset=utf8'
print(r.encoding)  # 'utf-8'
print(r.text)  # '{"authenticated": true, ...'
print(r.json())  # {'authenticated': True, ...}
pypiData.additionalInfo: Requests is one of the most downloaded Python packages today, pulling in around 30M downloads/week. According to GitHub, Requests is currently depended upon by 1,000,000+ repositories.

advancedUsage.title: Using Sessions
advancedUsage.description: Sessions allow you to persist cookies and other parameters across requests:
advancedUsage.example:
import requests

s = requests.Session()
s.auth = ('user', 'pass')
s.headers.update({'x-test': 'true'})

# Both requests will use the session's auth and headers
r1 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/headers')
r2 = s.get('https://httpbin.org/user')
